awd_titl_txt: Data-driven, biologically constrained biophysical computational model of the hippocampal network at full scale
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to fundamentally improve our understanding of the brain.  In particular, this project will construct a detailed, biologically realistic, computational model of the brain hippocampus.  The hippocampus is a major component of the brain that plays an important role in memory and other major human functions.  This detailed computational model of the hippocampus will allow researchers to understand the origins of specific behavioral level features of the brain, as well as treatment effectiveness for conditions such as epilepsy.  In addition, the project aims to investigate brain changes under different radiation exposure regimes.  Furthermore, the software infrastructure developed in the project, as well as simulation results, will be publicly released to the wider neuroscience community.

The overarching goal of the research projects is the construction of realistic and biophysically detailed computational models of the three major neuronal circuit layers in the hippocampus: the dentate gyrus (DG), CA3, and CA1. These three regions of the hippocampus are interconnected, and therefore the computational aspects of this research require building a detailed data-driven, full-scale computational model of the entire hippocampal formation and its inputs from the septum and the entorhinal cortex.  Information processing in the brain is organized and facilitated by the complex interactions of intrinsic biophysical properties of distinct neuronal types, neuronal morphology, and network connection topology. These properties give rise to specific types of network oscillations and other dynamic processes that govern neural information encoding and exchange. The hypotheses in this proposal are designed to create a detailed picture at unprecedented scale of how the intrinsic properties of hippocampal principal neurons and interneurons define the network activity under normal conditions, and how pathological changes in those properties under epileptic conditions disrupt hippocampal function.  The project has made public releases of the CA1 model code and simulation management tool (SimTracker), and have also published the CA1 simulation datasets that accompany the publication describing the main results of the CA1 work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neurons in the hippocampus and cortex have been shown to encode different representations of spatial information. Understanding the relationships between these representations is a fundamental open problem in neuroscience.  Thus, the overarching goal of our computational research projects is to construct the first full-scale biophysically detailed computational models of the three major neuronal circuit layers in the hippocampus: the dentate gyrus (DG), CA3, and CA1, and use these models to understand the principles of memory storage and retrieval in the brain.

Thanks to our generous computing allocations on the Frontera supercomputer, we have developed highly scalable and flexible parallel computing infrastructure for neuronal network modeling and optimization, and have used it to systematically analyze key information processing properties of our full-scale hippocampal models, and determine optimal parameters that allow the model to generate sparse and spatially selective population activity that fits well with in vivo experimental data.

The results of our work obtained through computational simulation indicate that (1) the selective responses of hippocampal neurons to spatially-modulated overlapping inputs are primarily a consequence of the structure of their synaptic weights; (2) short-term plasticity in NMDA receptors may lead to temporal integration of synaptic inputs that increases the robustness of a neuron's response to a particular location; (3) functional synaptic clustering may provide an additional boost to the signal-to-noise ratio in neuronal responses and further refine the selectivity of the postsynaptic neuron (4) synaptic clusters in the range of few hundred synapses are most effective in achieving high signal-to-noise ratio.

The unique features and scalability of our computational infrastructure has allowed us to rapidly generate on the Frontera supercomputer synaptic weight distributions for hundreds of thousands of neurons in our models, and has allowed us to recapitulate at an unprecendented scale the spatial selectivity of neurons in the hippocampus, which has been linked with spatial navigation in rodents.

A further aspect of this work, the computational modeling of epilepsy-related pathological alterations in zebrafish has revealed the importance of highly-connected hub nodes ("superhubs") in the spread of seizures, and suggest important potential targets for pharmacological interventions.

Importantly, most biophysical circuit models of the mammalian brain have treated the target brain region as homogeneous, with networks that consist of populations of neurons with identical intrinsic properties and synaptic connectivity. Yet the existing evidence points to significant anatomical and functional differentiation of the hippocampal microcircuitry along its three principal anatomical axes.

Large-scale biophysical modeling provides the ability to represent detailed gradients in intrinsic neuronal and synaptic properties, connection and input patterns, as well as to define long-distance projections that otherwise would not be possible. Coupled with our efficient software infrastructure for the rapid generation and simulations of models of hypotheses about neuronal structure and function, large-scale modeling can provide detailed understanding how the interactions between local properties and network organization of brain regions shapes overall information processing in the brain.

Thus, our computational models form an exploratory infrastructure that
can be used to generate specific hypotheses about brain function on   scale that has not been possible before.  Understanding the mechanistic processes that underlie cognition can have profound effects on society, from treatment of neurological disorders, to improved methods for education and training, and perhaps new insights about human decision making.
